summary.p: Bullinger has nothing interesting to share with Myconius, but writes because he has a reliable messenger [...]

- Friends wrote from Hesse [HBBW XV, No. 2305, and a letter not preserved] about the cruel plans of [Duke Heinrich of] Brunswick. In his camp, they found shields that he intended to attach to the gates of the [conquered] cities after his victory: One with his insignia of power for granting mercy to those who would surrender (while those who resisted would have been executed). The other shield with torches and brooms as a sign that the respective city would be set on fire and swept clean. That such a tyrant is now treated mildly is indeed fitting! [The friends from Hesse] also write that nothing has been decided about the tyrant yet, and that the younger [Karl Viktor] in Kassel [correct: Marburg] frequently plays ball. The letter was written on December 9 [1545] in Marburg.
- The messenger can provide information about the [Zürich] affairs.
- Bullinger's last letter [HBBW XV, No. 2314] was delivered by the citizen of Wil [Thomas Grunder].

div.p: Grace and innocence of life from the Lord. Because I had a reliable messenger, I wanted to write, at least so as not to remain completely silent. Otherwise, I have nothing to say that would be of great importance for you to know.

Friends write from Hesse about the utterly cruel plans of [Duke Heinrich of] Brunswick. In the camp, paintings were found that he intended to affix to the gates of the cities after victory. One indeed had the insignia of the tyrant: signs of clemency, yet tyrannical; for that city was not to be devastated, but plundered with those resisting being killed, and those surrendering being accepted. The other had a torch and brooms: a sign that the city should be reduced to ashes by fire so that it could be swept with brooms. Indeed, such a tyrant is deservedly received and treated most mercifully! They add that nothing has yet been decided about the prince or tyrant; the younger [Karl Viktor] frequently plays ball in Kassel. The letters were written in Marburg, December 9.
The messenger here can report to you about our affairs. Farewell with all good people and friends. Zürich, January 3, 1546.
I assume the last letter was delivered to you by the citizen of Wil. Greet Mr. Gast.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Oswald Myconius, the most faithful minister of the Basel church, his always esteemed lord and brother.
